thread.title: The papers: PM's meeting with Sturgeon dominates
thread.title_full: The papers: PM's meeting with Sturgeon dominates

title: The papers: PM's meeting with Sturgeon dominates
text: Messenger Image caption The government should light a "bonfire of EU red tape" when Article 50 is triggered on Wednesday, the Daily Telegraph writes. The newspaper says senior MPs and business leaders back its calls for the Tories to sweep aside "needless" EU regulations. Image caption Business leaders, army veterans and senior civil servants could run police forces under government plans, The Times reports. It says the proposals will cause "anger" among those in the police service. Image caption Pro-EU Conservatives are urging Prime Minister Theresa May, to concentrate on securing a good post-Brexit trade agreement - not just the cost - when leaving the 28-member bloc, the Guardian reports. Image caption Theresa May and Nicola Sturgeon's meeting - which took place days before Brexit negotiations are triggered - leads the i paper, which says their talks ended in stalemate. Image caption The FT leads on Tesco's bid to buy the food wholesaler Booker, but also finds room on the front page for the failure to find a solution to Northern Ireland's political deadlock. Image caption The Daily Mail leads with cost-saving plans for the NHS which involve cutting gluten-free food and cough remedies, it claims. It also highlights the legs of Prime Minister Theresa May and Scotland's first minister Nicola Sturgeon. Image caption The Daily Mirror leads with more on the terror attack in London, including the speed it is thought Khalid Masood drove at during his rampage on Westminster Bridge. Image caption George Michael could have been buried under the cover of darkness, writes the Daily Star. The paper says that late singer's partner - Fadi Fawaz - posted a picture of a moonlit graveyard, fuelling speculation over Michael's burial. Image caption Price comparison website uSwitch makes the front page of the Sun, which says it is "hiding" the best energy deals. Image caption The Express carries a claim from the former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith that the EU owes the UK "billions of pounds". The former work and pensions secretary said it was "nonsense" that Brexit negotiations could cost the UK up to Â£60bn, the paper adds.
